title: open_hat
body: Any headwear that atypically leaves the crown of the head exposed, either by design or due to [[torn hat|damage]]. Note that this excludes headwear that already has applicable terminology on Danbooru - such as [[visor cap]]s being the 'open' variant of [[baseball cap]]s. One example of an open hat is the [[chinese clothes|traditional Chinese]] "Cooling hat"/"Hakka hat" (Liangmao). This bears resemblance to [[ajirogasa]], with the exception of a circular cutout in its middle. This modification is applied to keep the wearer's head cool in hot weather. [tn]Other terms: capless hat, half-hat, topless hat[/tn]

body:
A [[Vspo!]] [[virtual YouTuber]]. Character designed by [[Yuu (Higashi no penguin)|]]. 

h4. Appearance
[tn]See post #5729972.[/tn]

She is portrayed with [[short hair|short]] [[blue hair]] with [[white hair|white]] [[streaked hair|streaks]] and a [[braid]] on her right, [[red eyes]], and [[medium breasts]]. 

Her default outfit consists of a [[long sleeves|long-sleeved]] [[off shoulder]] [[blue jacket]] in a [[midriff]] style, [[white shirt|white]] [[crop top]], [[white pants]] with the right leg [[single pantsleg|cropped to shorts-level]], [[single sock|single kneehigh]] on her right leg, white [[sneakers]], and a [[black choker]]. title: pearlescentmoon_(5am)
body:
An [[official alternate costume]] for [[PearlescentMoon]] in the [[Traffic Life series]]. In this costume, she wears a [[red cloak]] with a [[hood]], a [[white shirt]], and [[black shorts]]. It is worn during a few different seasons when Pearl is in distress or an unhinged state, such as being on her red life or when infected in [[secret life smp|Season 5]].

This design has had multiple pieces of official merchandise made for it, including a figure and a plush.

title: kazama_jin
body:
Kazama Jin is one of the main characters of the [[Tekken]] series.

First appearing in [[Tekken 3]], Jin is the son of [[Kazama Jun]] and [[Mishima Kazuya]]. He was raised by his mother; Jun, for most of his young life until he turned 15, when his mother was supposedly murdered by [[Ogre (Tekken)|]], an ancient being known as "Toshin, the God of Fighting." He was taken in by his grandfather, [[Mishima Heihachi]] who taught him Mishima Style Karate. Jin was able to defeat Ogre, winning the King of Iron Fist Tournament 3 but was betrayed and almost shot dead by Heihachi.

From [[Tekken 4]] onward, he would use traditional Karate instead of Mishima style to fall more in line with his mother's teachings and to distance himself from his Mishima heritage. In [[Tekken 5]], his [[dark persona]], [[Devil Jin]] became a playable character, using his moveset from games prior to Tekken 4. 

In [[Tekken 6]], after defeating [[Mishima Jinpachi]] in the previous tournament. Jin was declared the new head of the Mishima Zaibatsu. He used his new leadership to wage a world war, and to host the King of Iron Fist Tournament 6. However, he was bested by [[Lars Alexandersson]].

Jin is characterized by his altruism, as evident by his interactions with [[Ling Xiaoyu]] and [[Hwoarang (Tekken)|]]. He plans to end the Mishima bloodline by killing Heihachi, Kazuya and then himself. 

Jin's outfits usually consist of black pants or hooded jackets with a flame motif. In Tekken 3 and [[Tekken Tag Tournament]], he had a school uniform alternate costume alongside Xiaoyu, as they both attended the same high school. In Tekken 6, he wears a business suit alternate costume and an emperor outfit designed by [[CLAMP (circle)|]]. His [[Tekken 7]] outfit was designed by [[Kozaki Yuusuke]].
* !post #1041503: Tekken 4 Outfit from [[Namco X Capcom]]
* !post #426880: Common Gi design since Tekken 3 (pict. Tekken 6)
* !post #487332: Business Suit from Tekken 6
* !post #477124: CLAMP Emperor Outfit From Tekken 6
* !asset #22244652: Concept Art from Tekken 7

title: goreshit
body:
An UK-based electronic music producer, often regarded as a pioneer in the [Lolicore](https://rateyourmusic.com/genre/lolicore/) genre. Goreshit originally began in 2005 as a two-piece black metal band featuring Leon Makepeace and Shred Wilson but eventually turned into Leon's solo project.

title: about:note_fonts
body: The font of a translation note can be altered from the site default by using the CSS property [code]font-family[/code]. h4. Usage Add the property name and desired font name to the [b]style[/b] attribute of the surrounding HTML block. * Example: [code]This text will use a serif font[/code] h4. Name specification Single word fonts can be used as is. Multiple word fonts usually must be surrounded by apostrophes. * Example: [code]This text will use the Times New Roman font[/code] h4. Generic fonts There are five generic fonts which are available on all systems. The browser will pick the first available preferred font available on the user's OS. The generic font names are: * serif * sans-serif * monospace * cursive * fantasy h4. Multiple fonts The [code]font-family[/code] property allows multiple fonts to be listed as fallback fonts. Each font name needs to be separated by a comma. The browser will use the first available font from among those listed. * Example: [code]This text will use a font[/code] In the above example, if Times New Roman is on the system, the browser will use that font. Otherwise it will pick its preferred serif font. [tn][b]Note:[/b] It is generally suggested to always end a font list with a generic font. Otherwise, the font used will be dependent upon the browser.[/tn] h4. Danbooru-supplied fonts Danbooru supplies a set list of fonts available to use which acts as a guarantee that that font will be available to use on every browser and OS. * [b]comic[/b] - "Comic Relief":[https://fontlibrary.org/en/font/comic-relief], a Comic Sans replacement. * [b]narrow[/b] - "Archivo Narrow":[https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Archivo+Narrow], an Arial Narrow replacement. Narrow and thin. * [b]mono[/b] - "IBM's Plex Mono":[https://fonts.google.com/specimen/IBM+Plex+Mono], a monospace font for use on code or robot-like text. * [b]slab sans[/b] - "Anton":[https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Anton], an Impact replacement. Narrow and thick. * [b]slab serif[/b] - "Rokkitt":[https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Rokkitt], a Rockwell replacement. A blocky serif font. Sometimes used for comic titles. * [b]formal serif[/b] - "Lora":[https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Lora], a rounded, more formal serif font. * [b]formal cursive[/b] - "Petit Formal Script":[https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Petit+Formal+Script], a fancy cursive font. * [b]print[/b] - "Kalam":[https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Kalam], a neatly hand-printed font. Comparable to MV Boli. Suitable for neat handwriting or comics. * [b]hand[/b] - "Indie Flower":[https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Indie+Flower], a more casual handwritten font. Comparable to Segoe Print. * [b]childlike[/b] - "Giselle Script":[https://www.1001freefonts.com/gisele-script.font], a more-heavily stylized handwritten font. It has a lot of nice simple loops typical of what one might find in a children's course on teaching the alphabet. * [b]blackletter[/b] - "Unifraktur Maguntia":[https://fonts.google.com/specimen/UnifrakturMaguntia], a Gothic / Germanic / Old English style font. * [b]scary[/b] - "Anarchy":[https://www.dafont.com/anarchy-2.font], with jagged wild strokes. [tn][b]Note:[/b]The multiple word fonts that Danbooru provides do not need to be surrounded by apostrophes. Only the bolded font aliases will work, not the actual font names. For example, use [code]hand[/code], not [code]'Indie Flower'[/code].[/tn] Additionally, the following standard fonts have been aliased to other fonts: * [b]Comic Sans MS[/b] is now aliased to [b]Comic Relief[/b]. * [b]Arial Narrow[/b] is now aliased to [b]Archivo Narrow[/b]. * [b]Rockwell[/b] is now aliased to [b]Rokkitt[/b]. * [b]Impact[/b] is now aliased to [b]Anton[/b]. [tn]Using specific fonts besides the Danbooru-supplied and generic font families is discouraged and support for them will be removed in the future.[/tn] h5. Preview * !asset #22237761: Regular * !asset #22237764: [b]Bold[/b] * !asset #22237806: [i]Italic[/i] * !asset #22237893: [b][i]Bold & Italic[/i][/b] h4. See also * topic #16435 - Discussion on Danbooru-supported fonts * [[About:Note Formatting]]

title: suggestive_fluid
body:
An innocent liquid presented in [[sexually suggestive]] way.

A common example is when a character is covered in something that looks like [[cum]] (or, less commonly, [[pussy juice]] or [[pee|urine]]), but is actually something innocent like [[ice cream]], [[milk]], [[mayonnaise]], [[sweat]], or [[lotion]].

Don't tag actual [[cum]] as a suggestive fluid. Unknown fluids that look like cum should be treated as cum if there are no context clues to suggest otherwise.

Use [[ambiguous red liquid]] when the fluid looks like blood but you are unsure.

h4. See also

* [[sexually suggestive]]
* [[Kefir]]
* [[Pulque]]

title: chidori_(nobunaga_no_shinobi)
body:
An extremely skilled shinobi that is also very clumsy. She was saved from drowning by [[oda nobunaga (nobunaga no shinobi)|Nobunaga]] as a young girl, and thus wants to serve him with all her strength. She is shown to be so skilled that she is able to easily take on one of the leading male ninjas from Koga who has had years of training (though is defeated through her own idiocy). She is also able to persuade many political leaders to Nobunaga's side.

Voiced by: [[Minase Inori]]

title: oda_nobunaga_(nobunaga_no_shinobi)
body:
The first leading unifier of Japan since the collapse of the old shogunate, who throughout the series works to defeat other daimyos to bring peace to the land. He saved [[Chidori (Nobunaga no Shinobi)|Chidori]] from drowning when she was young, thus earning her loyalty. He is a very skilled commander, beating out many other daimyos and gaining the support of the Shogun. His three weaknesses, as listed by Chidori, are Oichi (his younger sister), [[alcohol]], and [[sweets]].

Voiced by: [[Hatano Wataru]]

title: winding_key
body:

[[Shinonome Nano]] of [[Nichijou]] is well known for having this key on her back.

h4. See also

* [[Pull cord]]

title: ripcord
body:
A cord or chain [[pulling|pulled]] to deploy a [[parachute]], engine (of a [[motor vehicle|motor]] [[boat]] or [[chainsaw]]), or [[Beyblade]].

h4. See also

* [[Pull cord]]

title: pull_cord
body:
A pull cord is a mechanism that operates a device by means of pulling a cord. Common examples include:

* Cords connected to the built in switch of an electric [[lamp]] particularly common on certain types of [[ceiling light]]s.
* Cords that would wind up the voice mechanism of older mechanical talking [[doll]]s and [[toy]]s. These often have a ring-shaped handle. 
* Cords used for starting small engines without a starter motor (e.g. on a [[lawnmower|push-mower]] or [[chainsaw]]). These often have a T-shaped handle.

h4. See also

* [[Ripcord]]
* [[Winding key]]

title: 114514_(meme)
body:
A popular meme from [[Manatsu No Yo No Inmu]] that made its way to [[Cookie (touhou)|]] as well.  

From comment #2010702:
Like all numbers in this picture, it's Japanese number code.
1 = i(chi)
4 = shi/yo
5 = go/ko

So it can be translated as 'iiyo, koi yo' or 'all right, cum!'

Other related numbers that sometimes appear as well:
1919: Saying each number invidually becomes "i ku i ku", which sounds like "cum, cum"
810: Can be split into "8 10", then translated as "ya ju", for [[Yajuu Senpai]]
3777: Sa(n) na(na) na(na) na(na) = [[Sananana (cookie)|]]
364364: 見ろよ、見ろよ, said by [[Miura Daisenpai]]

title: ensign_nogami
body:
A fictional male character from [[The Cockpit: Sonic Boom Squadron]] OVA episode from 1993.

[b]Ensign Yasushi Nogami[/b] ([b]Yasushi Nonaka[/b] in the original manga) is the young (but serious) [[kamikaze pilot]] of an [[mxy-7 ohka|Ohka]] rocket plane.

title: aniyome_wa_ijippari
body:
[b]Aniyome wa Ijippari[/b] ([I]My brother's wife is messing with me[/I]), is a Hentai visual novel developed and published by Tinkerbell that was released in 2007. The game would later have a two episode Hentai ova that was released in 2008.

The player takes the role of [[Katsuragi Tsutomu]], where through the player's choices, Tsutomu has an affair with either or both with, [[Katsuragi Mai]], his sister in law, and [[Takama Kozue]], his coworker and Mai's senpai.

title: neuvillette_(genshin_impact)
body:
A playable [[Genshin Impact]] character released in Version 4.1. The Chief Justice of Fontaine, known as the Iudex, and second-in-command to the Hydro Archon, [[Furina_(genshin_impact)|]]. He appears serious, aloof and perfectly impartial befitting his position, but is a genuinely kind person who can be socially awkward at times due to his unfamiliarity with human customs and feelings. The [[Melusine_(genshin_impact)|]]s see him as their father figure. 

Because of their similarities in appearance, he’s often associated with the [[Leisurely Otter (genshin impact)|]]. His true identity though is [spoilers]the incumbent Hydro Dragon Sovereign[/spoilers]. 

h4. Appearance

* !post #6591396

Neuvillette is often depicted with [[tsurime]] eyes, giving him a sharp appearance. He wears a [[white ascot]] over his clothing, and his [[very long hair|hair]] is styled in a [[low-tied_long_hair|low-tied]] ponytail. 
For legwear, he dons [[black footwear|black]] [[thigh boots]] with [[thighhigh gaiters]].

h4. External links

* "Genshin Impact Wiki: Neuvillette":[https://genshin-impact.fandom.com/wiki/Neuvillette]

title: jessica_rabbit
body: Jessica Rabbit is a fictional character from the novel [i]Who Censored Roger Rabbit?[/i] by Gary K. Wolf, and its loose film adaptation, [i]Who Framed Roger Rabbit[/i]. She is depicted as Roger's human toon wife in various Roger Rabbit media. Jessica is renowned as one of the most well known sex symbols in animation.[1] She is also well known for her movie quote "I'm not bad. I'm just drawn that way."

[b]666[/b], the [b]Number of the Beast[/b] is the numerical value of the name of the person symbolised by the [i]beast from the sea[/i], the first of two symbolic beasts described in chapter 13 of the Book of Revelation.

h4. See also

* [[demon]]

h4. External links

title: three-headed_dragon_(meme)
body:
A meme format based around a drawing of a [[multiple heads|three-headed]] [[dragon]]; the first two stare at the viewer with very fearsome looks, while the the third dragon head has a noticeably goofy one. The 2nd dragon head looks at the 3rd dragon head with its eyebrow raised.

It originates from a drawing of [[King Ghidorah]] by artist Michael J. Larson.

title: production_art
body:
A catch-all tag for either unfinished works in progress that lead to a final production work, or ancillary reference materials used in the production of a work. This is almost always [[official art]], with the exception of production work of individual doujin [[animated|animations]].

This includes [[unfinished]] and [[making-of]] materials such as:

* works drawn on [[animation paper]] to be used as with a [[peg bar]], or featuring [[trim marks]] for later editing
* [[color trace]]s
* [[partially colored]] art (when a reference or a piece of pre-production artwork)
* [[key frame]]s
* [[animatic]]s (very rough pre-production [[animated|animations]])
* [[photo (medium)|]]s or [[scan]]s of physical [[cel]]s used in a traditionally animated work

As well as production references such as:

* [[storyboard]]s
* [[reference sheet]]s
* [[information sheet]]s
* [[production note]]s
* [[color guide]]s
* official [[height chart]]s and [[costume chart]]s
* [[promotional art]] used in the advertisement of a work

title: pop-up_pirate
body:
A popular board game manufactured by Tomy. Original Japanese title: 黒ひげ危機一発 ([i]Kurohige Kiki Ippatsu[/i], The crisis of Blackbeard).

Players take turns sticking small plastic swords in a small barrel until a spring-loaded pirate pops out. Players play until they are eliminated by popping out the pirate and the one player remaining who has not popped the pirate wins.

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Pop-up Pirate":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pop-up_Pirate]

title: ulterior_motives_(song)
body:
Pop song by Christopher and Philip Booth, made in the 1980s and featured in the pornographic film [[Angels of Passion]]. It became one of the most well known cases of lost media when a 17-second clip of the song went viral online under the nickname "Everyone Knows That". 

The song is often associated with a pink [[boombox]], because of an image that was often attached to posts about the song.

A remastered version of the song released in 2024.

h4. External links
* "Ulterior Motives (song)":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ulterior_Motives_(song) on Wikipedia

title: takeuchi_naoko
body:
[b]Takeuchi Naoko[/b] (b. March 15, 1967) is the creator and artist of [i][[codename_wa_sailor_v|Codename: Sailor V]][/i] and [i][[Bishoujo Senshi Sailor Moon]][/i]. She is married to [[Togashi Yoshihiro]], the creator of [i][[Yu Yu Hakusho]][/i] and [i][[Hunter x Hunter]][/i].

The Bishoujo Senshi Sailor Moon Original Picture Collections are artbooks compiling the color illustrations drawn by Takeuchi Naoko during each year of the manga.

title: ootachi
body:
A type of Japanese [[sword]]. The ootachi (also known as 野太刀, [i]"nodachi"[/i]) is essentially a [[katana]] with a very long blade, often longer than the wielder's height. The best-known examples are probably [[Sephiroth]]'s Masamune in [i][[Final Fantasy VII]][/i] and the various long sword-class weapons featured in the [i][[Monster Hunter (series)|]][/i] series.

The ootachi was a rare weapon. In real life, it was used by men on foot to fight against mounted cavalry, however [[polearm]]s were much easier to produce and in most cases were more effective in that role. Due to it being an expensive weapon that was difficult to forge, it was seen as proof of a swordsmith's skill and a status symbol for a samurai who carried it.

h4. See also
* [[Nagamaki]] - the inverse of ootachi where the handle was lengthened instead of the blade
* [[Greatsword]]
* [[List of Weapons]]

title: scp-173
body:
Subject of the [[SCP Foundation]], and notably the first SCP ever written. Crude [[statue]] which is animate when not being observed. Known for incredible speed and violent interactions with living beings.

Popularized the "SCP" fiction and is featured in fanmade projects such as [i]SCP: Containment Breach[/i]. Appearance originally based on a statue by artist Katou Izumi, until it was "phased out":https://twitter.com/scpwiki/status/1488632353199063040 in 2022.

h4. External links

* "SCP Wiki: SCP-173":http://www.scp-wiki.net/scp-173

title: thumb_in_beltline
body:
When a character's thumb is inserted into their legwear's beltline (i.e. at the top of their hip), either to remove that piece of garment or as a some sort of "dynamic" posture (such as [[hand on own hip]]).

Note that this tag only applies if the thumb is on the beltline position, and as such it is not applicable when character is moving their thumb below that area (such as [[panty pull]]).

title: moe-chan_(moechannel)
body:
Mascot of [[MoeChannel]], the store of the artist [[onlinepetclub]].

She has [[short hair|short]] [[pink hair]] and [[blue eyes]]. She wears a [[pink dress]] with a [[white apron]], [[mismatched legwear]] (one [[purple thighhighs|purple thighhigh]] with a [[star print]], one [[white thighhighs|white thighhigh]] with a [[kaomoji]] print), a [[white hat]], [[white gloves|white]] [[paw gloves]] with [[pawpads]], and [[white footwear|white]] [[paw shoes]]. The front of her dress features a [[pink bow]] with an [[error message]] symbol.

Her outfit contains elements based on various 2000s anime-related characters, such as [[Mayura]], [[ME-tan]], and [[Nakahara Komugi]].

title: honey_the_cat
body:
A [[sonic_(series)|Sonic]] character based off of [[honey_(fighting_vipers)|Honey]] from [i][[Fighting Vipers]][/i], a fighting game series also by Sega. 

She was originally meant to appear in [i]Sonic the Fighters[/i] and even had a complete model and moveset, but was ultimately scrapped from the arcade game for unknown reasons. However, her data was still present within the game, ergo making it possible to still play as her via hacking. Honey was eventually restored into [i]Sonic the Fighters[/i] officially when it was remastered for its digital release on Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 in 2012. Just highlight Amy, press the start button, and then select! 

Honey would make further appearances as a prominent character in the Sonic comics published by Archie Comics and made a cameo in the Sonic the Hedgehog Free Comic Book Day 2021 issue by IDW Publishing.

title: between_thighs
body:
For when an object is situated or held between a person's thighs.  Note that most sexual connotations are covered by, and should be marked with, their own tags listed below.

Alternatively, [[hand_between_legs|hands]] (or [[tail_between_legs|tails]], arms etc.) placed between the thighs, usually in a coy manner.

An entire person in such a position is [[between legs]].

h4. See also

* [[crotch rope]]
* [[crotch rub]]

* [[grinding]]

title: onbuhimo
body: A manner of carrying [[baby|babies]] in historical Japan. A chord or sash (himo) is tied over a [[kimono]], and the baby is placed under the kimono, against the parent's back or front, where the chord is tied over the kimono to keep them secured. The practice of carrying a child against one's skin in Japan stems from the cultural practice of encouraging skinship between mother and child. This was believed to promote healthy development in the child. Along with that, mothers were not always exempt from work - historical accounts of women in Japan will show that women would do manual labor with their baby strapped to their back. For a baby that is carried with clothing that isn't shared, see [[baby carrier]].

title: kochou_shinobu
body:
Shinobu Kocho is a major supporting character of Demon Slayer: [[Kimetsu no Yaiba]].

Shinobu has [[pale skin]] and [[purple eyes]]. She has [[two-tone hair|two-tone]] [[black hair|black]] [[wavy hair]] that [[gradient hair|fades]] to dark [[purple hair|purple]], styled at the back of her head into a [[hair_bun|bun]], fastened with a  [[butterfly hair ornament]]. She has [[parted bangs]] that flow down to frame the sides of her face, with two [[sidelocks]] below them. 

Shinobu wears a standard [[Demon Slayer uniform]] with gold [[buttons]], consisting of a [[black jacket]] and matching colored [[tabi]] socks and [[hakama]] pants, tucked into [[white belt]]. Over her uniform, she wears a [[animal print|butterfly patterned]] [[haori]] that previously belonged to her older sister. She wears white [[waraji]] sandals with purple straps for footwear, with a hidden blade in one of the heels.

title: playdia
body:
A home video game console that was launched in 1994 by [[Bandai]].
When compared to other systems launched around the same time, such as Sony's [[PlayStation 1]] and the [[Sega Saturn]] etc., with the exception of the MPEG playback function, it fell behind in all other categories, and was a commercial failure.
Other failed game consoles that Bandai has launched include the "Intellivision: Japan Import":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intellivision#History_and_development], "the Bandai/Emerson Arcadia":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arcadia_2001], the "Vectrex/Kousokusen":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vectrex], and the "Apple/Bandai Pippin Atmark":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Bandai_Pippin]. Today these consoles are only alluded to in jokes. 

h4.External links

* "Wikipedia article":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Playdia

h4.See also
* [[List of game consoles]]
* [[Tag Group:Video Game]]

title: sega_saturn
body:
The [b]Sega Saturn[/b] is a 32-bit fifth-generation [[video game]] console that was first released by [[Sega]] on November 22, 1994 in Japan, May 11, 1995 in North America, and July 8, 1995 in Europe. The system was discontinued in North America and Europe in 1998, and in 2000 in Japan.

While it had stronger sales in [[Japan]], it did not fare so well in North America and Europe. It also couldn't compete against the [[Nintendo 64]] and [[Sony]] [[Playstation 1]] at the time. The Saturn was preceded by the 16-bit [[Sega Mega Drive]] and succeeded by the [[Sega Dreamcast]].

h4. See also
* [[List of game consoles]]
* [[Tag Group:Video Game]]

title: battlefield_3
body:
[b]Battlefield 3[/b] is a first-person shooter video game developed by EA DICE and published by [[Electronic Arts]]. It was released in 25 October 2011 for various gaming platforms, including [[PlayStation 3]], [[Xbox 360]], and PC.

The game is known for its modern military setting and its single-player and multiplayer experiences. The single-player campaign generally follows the story of [[united states marine corps|U.S. Marine]] Sergeant Henry "Black" Blackburn and is set in various locations around the world, including [[Iran]], [[New York City]], and [[Paris]]. The narrative focuses on a conflict between the [[United States]] and an organization known as the People's Liberation and Resistance, a fictional Iranian paramilitary insurgent group based largely in the Middle East.

The game received praise for its impressive graphics, dynamic environments, and realistic gameplay mechanics. The game was highly acclaimed for its multiplayer mode, which allows for large-scale battles and emphasizes teamwork, vehicular combat, and destructible environments. The multiplayer component featured various classes, a wide array of vehicles, and diverse map designs, offering players a range of strategic options during gameplay.

The Frostbite 2 game engine, used in Battlefield 3 allowed for impressive visuals and realistic destruction within the game environment, contributing to the game's overall immersive experience. The title was well-received for its multiplayer innovation and its focus on providing a more realistic and teamwork-driven experience compared to other shooters on the market at the time.

h4. External links
* "Wikipedia: Battlefield 3":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battlefield_3]
* "Wikipedia: Battlefield (video game series)":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battlefield_(video_game_series)]

h4. See Also
* [[battlefield_(series)|List of other Battlefield titles]]

title: call_of_duty:_advanced_warfare
body:
[b]Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare[/b] is a first-person shooter video game developed by Sledgehammer Games and published by [[Activision]]. It was released in November 2014 for various gaming platforms, including [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]], and PC.

The game is set in the mid-21st century and features futuristic warfare, introducing advanced technology and [[exoskeleton]] suits that enhance the abilities of the soldiers. The gameplay includes high-tech weaponry, gadgets, and futuristic equipment, allowing players to perform superhuman feats such as double jumps and boost dodges.

The story follows Jack Mitchell, a soldier who joins a private military corporation called Atlas after the loss of his arm during a mission. The company is led by Jonathan Irons, portrayed by actor Kevin Spacey, and the narrative revolves around the consequences of privatized military power and the use of advanced technology in warfare.

The game was well-received for its gameplay innovations, particularly the exoskeleton mechanics that added a new dimension to the typical Call of Duty experience. The game also included a robust multiplayer mode with various customization options and introduced new movement mechanics that allowed for faster-paced, more vertical gameplay.

h4. External links
* "Wikipedia: Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty:_Advanced_Warfare]
* "Wikipedia: Call of Duty":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Call_of_Duty]

h4. See Also
* [[Call of Duty|List of other Call of Duty titles]]

title: wild_arms
body:
The [[Wild Arms]] series as a whole. See [[Wild Arms 1]] for the first title in the series.

The original [i]Wild Arms[/i] game was released by Media Vision in 1997 on the [[Playstation 1]], one of the first RPGs for the console. It would become overlooked in favor of Squaresoft's [[Final Fantasy VII]], which was released around the same time. Despite this setback, the series still remains popular in Japan, and its tenth anniversary was celebrated in 2007 with a large number of cameos in [[Wild Arms 5]] and a limited edition artbook.

The setting for the games is consistently a combination of Western and science-fiction tropes, and each story takes place on a (usually dying and/or war-ravaged) world known as Filgaia.

There are six Wild Arms games, an anime series, and a manga associated with the series:

* [[Wild Arms 1]] - [i]Wild Arms Alter Code F[/i] (re-release title)
* [[Wild Arms 2]] - [i]Wild Arms 2nd Ignition[/i]
* [[Wild Arms 3]] - [i]Wild Arms Advanced 3rd[/i]
* [[Wild Arms 4]] - [i]Wild Arms the 4th Detonator[/i]
* [[Wild Arms 5]] - [i]Wild Arms the Vth Vanguard[/i] 
* [[Wild Arms XF]] - [i]Wild Arms Crossfire[/i]
* [[Wild Arms Twilight Venom]] anime
* [[Wild Arms Flower Thieves]] manga

h4.See also

* [[Armed Fantasia]]

title: x-men_vs._street_fighter
body:
[b][i]X-MEN VS. STREET FIGHTER[/i][/b] is a [[crossover]] fighting game developed by [[Capcom]] in [[1996]], released for arcades, [[Sega Saturn]] [i](Japan only)[/i], and [[PlayStation 1]]. In collaboration with [[Marvel|Marvel Comics]], this would be the third fighting game made by the joint companies. It was the first game to introduce 2-on-2 tag team fighting in the [[Marvel vs. Capcom]] series, featuring characters from [[X-Men]] and [[Street Fighter]] respectively. The game also introduced new mechanics such as Variable Combination and Variable Counter. 

The game's "intro":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8UWgGcRHCgU is noteworthy for its iconic handshake between Ryu and Cyclops which has been parodied by fans.

title: assault_suits_valken
body:
[i][b]Assault Suits Valken[/b][/i] (重装機兵ヴァルケン [i]Jūsō Kihei Varuken[/i]), released in the U.S.A. as [i][b]Cybernator[/b][/i], is a military [[science fiction]] side-scrolling [[mecha]] action [[video game]] developed by Masaya in 1992 for the [[Super Famicom]] Japanese home console and also for the [[Super Nintendo]] western console.

Valken is set in the far future and follows the adventures of a [[military]] mecha [[pilot]] during a devastating world conflict.

It is the second game in the [[Assault Suits Series]]. Valken is actually an indirect prequel/spin-off to the first game in the series, [[Assault Suit Leynos]], as Valken's plot takes place a whole 10 years before the events of Leynos.

A sequel called [i][b]Assault Suits Valken 2[/b][/i] was also released in 1999 for the [[PlayStation 1]] console only in Japan. The events of this game occur 30 years after the first Valken game and 20 years after the original Leynos.

The original Valken has since been re-released on the [[Wii]] as a Virtual Console product in Japan. A HD remake of the first game with new graphics has been also released for the [[PlayStation 2]] console in Japan, Europe and Australia in 2004.

h4. See also

* [[Valken]]
* [[Jake Brain]]
* [[Crea Coral]]

title: bokujou_monogatari
body:
A multi-system farming simulation video game series. The player moves onto an abandoned or inherited farm and must rejuvenate their new hometown.

Most well-known in the West as [i]Harvest Moon[/i] (1997-2013), when it was distributed by Natsume. In 2014, Natsume lost the license to the series, and as the rights to the [[Harvest Moon (natsume)|]] name in the West is owned by them, the series renamed itself to [i]Story of Seasons[/i] outside of Japan.

The video game series [i][[Rune Factory]][/i] is a spin-off of the Bokujou Monogatari series; taking the game elements of Bokujou Monogatari and combining them with fantasy RPG game elements. Since 2019, the series also collaborated with [[Doraemon]] franchise and released two [i]Doraemon's Story of Seasons[/i] spin-off series.

title: wolf_fang
body:
[b][i]Wolf Fang[/i][/b] (ウルフファング), fully titled as [b][i]Wolf Fang: Kuhga 2001[/i][/b] (ウルフファング 空牙2001), and known outside of Japan as [b][i]Rohga: Armor Force[/i][/b], is a 1991 run and gun/platform hybrid [[mecha]] arcade [[video game]] developed and published by [[Data East]]. It is part of the [[Kuhga]] trilogy.

[i]Wolf Fang[/i] is the sequel to [[kuhga|Vapor Trail: Hyper Offence Formation]] and was followed by [i][b]Skull Fang[/b][/i] ([[Kuhga Gaiden]]). The game focuses in 2D side-scrolling mecha shooting action instead of fighter jets. As the players control a mecha, they have the opportunity to arm it with different weapons. There are four types of mecha they can choose from, each one offering different attacks and stage of mobility as they can choose a standard humanoid mecha, a hovering mecha, a four legged [[walker (robot)|]] mecha and a six wheeled mecha. They can also assemble the mecha according to armaments and features of their own choosing. 

The player's mecha has up to eight points of health that when completely depleted, forces the player's mecha operator to eject safely.

[i]Wolf Fang[/i] was ported to the Sony [[PlayStation 1]] and [[Sega Saturn]] in 1996 and 1997 respectively by conversion company Xing.

The console versions have added features such as a new title screen, new introduction, an arranged soundtrack and a staff roll after the endings. The arcade versions outside Japan however, have a number of things cut. There is no story intermissions between the stages and there is no stage selection leading to 4 different endings found on the Japanese version, but the game cycles through all 12 stages like in the Japanese version's expert mode.

In 2010, [i]Wolf Fang[/i] was also added to the PlayStation Network to allow users to download to and play either on the [[PlayStation Portable]] or the [[PlayStation 3]].

title: metal_gear_2
body:
[i][b]Metal Gear 2: Solid Snake[/b][/i] is an overhead action-adventure stealth [[video game]] released by [[Konami]] for the [[MSX]]2 computer platform in 1990. 

It serves as a direct sequel to the MSX2 version of [[Metal Gear 1]], written and designed by series's creator [[Kojima Hideo]], who conceived the game in response to [i]Snake's Revenge[/i], a separately-produced sequel that was being developed at the time for the [[NES]] specifically for the North American and European markets. 

The MSX2 version of Solid Snake was only released in Japan, although Kojima would later direct another sequel titled [[Metal Gear Solid]], which was released worldwide for the [[PlayStation 1]] in 1998 to critical acclaim.

This later led to Solid Snake being re-released alongside the original Metal Gear as additional content in the Subsistence version of [[Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater]] for the [[PlayStation 2]] in 2005. It was also included in the HD remastered ports of Metal Gear Solid 3 released for the [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation Vita]] and [[Xbox 360]], and was given a stand-alone re-release in Japan as a downloadable game for mobile phones and the [[Wii]] Virtual Console.

Set in 1999, a few years after the events of the original game, [[Solid Snake]] must infiltrate a heavily defended territory known as Zanzibar Land to rescue a kidnapped scientist and destroy the revised "[[Metal Gear D]]" [[walker (robot)|]] [[mecha]]. The game significantly evolved the stealth-based game system of its predecessor "in almost every way", introduced a complex storyline dealing with themes such as the nature of warfare and nuclear proliferation, and is considered "one of the best 8 bit games ever made...".

title: metal_slug_2
body:
[b]Metal Slug 2[/b] is a run and gun [[video game]] developed by [[SNK]]. 

It was originally released in 1998 for the [[Neo Geo]] MVS [[arcade]] platform as the sequel to the 1996 game [[Metal Slug]]. 

The original version of the game had extensive slowdown and performance issues, eventually leading SNK to release a modified version titled [[Metal Slug X]]: Super Vehicle-001 (メタルスラッグX) in 1999. 

It has been ported to the Neo Geo CD, [[PlayStation 1]], Virtual Console, iOS and Android, and to the [[Wii]], [[PlayStation Portable]] and [[PlayStation 2]] (as part of the Metal Slug Anthology). 

The game added several new features to the gameplay of the original Metal Slug, such as new weapons, vehicles and the ability to transform the character. It received generally positive reviews.

h4. Characters introduced in Metal Slug 2

* [[Fio Germi]]
* [[Kasamoto Eri]]
* [[Aikawa Rumi]]
* [[Mars People]]
* [[Hyakutaro Ichimonji]]

title: tear_ring_saga
body:
Tear Ring Saga: Utna Heroes Saga (ティアリングサーガ ユトナ英雄戦記) is a Japanese Tactical role-playing-game directed and designed by Shouzou Kaga, the original creator of the [[Fire Emblem]] series, this game is a spiritual successor of his original series developed with his own company (Tirnanog) alongside publisher Enterbrain, originally released for the [[Playstation 1]] in May 24th, 2001.

The story follows the perspectives of the two main characters, [[Runan (Tear Ring Saga)|]]'s and [[Holmes (Tear Ring Saga)|]]'s, in a world fighting against the growing Zoa Empire.

Tear Ring Saga shares many elements with old school Fire Emblem in mechanics, aesthetics, tropes, etc. The game is, among other things, known for being part of a legal dispute between Shouzou Kaga (& his collaborators) and Nintendo (the Fire Emblem copyright holders) over the similarities between the two series, which ultimately ended up creating legal predecent for similar old-school inspired projects.

title: raystorm
body:
[b]RayStorm[/b] is a scrolling shooter developed by the [i]Taito Corporation[/i] (now part of [[Square Enix]]). Originally released in Japan as an arcade game in 1996, it was later ported there to [[Sony]]'s [[PlayStation 1]] game console in 1997, to the [[Sega Saturn]] (under the name [b]Layer Section II[/b]) in that same year, and to [[Microsoft Windows]]-based personal computers in 2001. In North America, it was released for the PlayStation by [i]Working Designs[/i] in June 1997. The PlayStation version was also released in Europe by [i]SCE Europe[/i]. It was re-released in 2010 with improved graphics, as [b]RayStorm HD[/b], for the [[Xbox 360]].

h4. See also

* [[RayCrisis]] (Chronologically 1st game in the [b]Ray[/b] trilogy)
* [[RayForce]] (Chronologically 2nd game in the [b]Ray[/b] trilogy)

h4. External links

title: policenauts
body:
[b]Policenauts[/b] (ポリスノーツ) is a cinematic adventure [[video game]] with a [[cyberpunk]] science fiction storyline, written and directed by [[Hideo Kojima]], and published by [[Konami]]. It was initially released for the PC-9821 computer platform in 1994, followed by remade versions for the 3DO in 1995, and the [[PlayStation 1]] and Sega Saturn in 1996. 

The game has never been officially released outside Japan, despite plans for an English localization of the [[Sega Saturn]] version. 

On August 24, 2009 (in honor of the 46th birthday of the game designer, Hideo Kojima), an unofficial English translation patch was released by fans in the internet.

Policenauts, like [[Snatcher]] before it, pays various homages to previously existing works. An obvious one is Jonathan's and Ed's (the main characters) respective resemblances to detectives Riggs and Murtaugh from the 80s police action film [i][[Lethal Weapon]][/i].

The game centers on a [[police]] [[detective]] called [[Jonathan Ingram]] who travels to a [[space]] colony to reunite with [[Ed Brown]], his former partner, and together they investigate the circumstances surrounding the sudden disappearance of the new husband of Jonathan's ex-wife. 

h4. See also

* [[Jonathan Ingram]]
* [[Ed Brown]]
* [[Meryl Silverburgh]]

title: dragon_quest_iv
body:
[i]Dragon Quest IV[/i] is the fourth installment of the [i][[Dragon Quest]][/i] video game series, and the last to appear on the [[Famicom]].

The game is divided into five chapters, each introducing one or more of the main characters and the final chapter gathering them together under the Hero/Heroine's leadership.

The main female characters are [[Alena (dq4)|]], [[Minea (dq4)|]] and [[Manya (dq4)|]]; there is also the option for a [[Heroine (DQ4)|female protagonist]]. A rarely drawn side character is [[Lucia (DQ)|]], who is a temporary party late in the game. Another is [[Cynthia (DQ4)|]], an elf girl who is the Hero/Heroine's childhood friend.

DQ4 introduced the [[Dancer's Costume (DQ)|Dancer's Costume]] and is the only Dragon Quest game to feature the [[Pink Leotard (DQ)|Pink Leotard]].

The game has been remade for the [[Playstation 1]], [[Nintendo DS]], and iOS/Android. The DS port is subtitled "Chapters of the Chosen" in English. The remakes also add an optional 6th chapter.

h4. Playable Characters

* [[Alena (DQ4)|Alena]]

* [[Manya (dq4)|]]
* [[Minea (dq4)|]]
* [[Ryan (DQ4)|Ryan]]
* [[Torneko]]

h4. Non-Playable Characters

title: getter_robo_daikessen!
body:
A [[Getter Robo]] strategy game released for [[PlayStation 1]] in 1999. The game crosses over characters, [[mecha]], and story elements from both the anime and manga versions of the [[getter Robo (1st series)|original Getter Robo]], [[Getter Robo G|G]], [[Getter Robo go|Go]], and the [[shin Getter Robo|Getter Robo Armageddon]] OVA.

Various brand new original Getter machines and characters were introduced in this game as well.

title: dragon_quest_vii
body:
The seventh game in the [i][[Dragon Quest]][/i] series, and the first to appear on a non-[[Nintendo]] console (the [[PlayStation 1]]).  It was released in 2000 in Japan, with an English version published in North America a year later.  An enhanced remake for the [[Nintendo 3DS]] was published in Japan in 2013.

It was the first game in the series to be released in America since [[Dragon Quest IV|the fourth]], and it would be the last to be released in that market under the [i]Dragon Warrior[/i] title.

title: raycrisis
body:
レイクライシス

[b]RayCrisis[/b], known as [b]RayCrisis: Series Termination[/b] in North America, is the third game released in the "[b]Ray[/b]" series of [i]Taito[/i] shooting games. Chronologically, it is considered a prequel to the first game, [[RayForce]]. First released for arcades in 1998, it supported co-op mode for two players, which the [[PlayStation 1]] ports released in 2000 lack; these ports are the only games in the "[b]Ray[/b]" series to lack co-op.

h4. See also

title: macross_ultimate_frontier
body:
The sequel to the [[Macross Ace Frontier]] [[Playstation Portable]] videogame. It was released during October 2009 only in [[Japan]].

New game elements include new variable fighters from the parallel universe of [[Macross 2]] and previous [[Playstation 1]] ([[Macross VF-X2]]) and [[Sega Dreamcast]] ([[Macross M3]]) games. 

It also contains new [[Macross]] characters created exclusively for the game by [[Mikimoto Haruhiko]].

title: gradius_ii
body:
[b]Gradius II: Gofer no Yabou[/b] (グラディウスII GOFERの野望  - [i]Gradiusu Tsū: Gofā no Yabō[/i]), also known as [b]Gradius II: Gofer's Ambition[/b] or [b]Vulcan Venture[/b] in [[arcade]]s outside Japan, is a [[science fiction]] 2D horizontally-scrolling space shooter [[video game]] originally released for the arcades in [[Japan]] in 1988. 

It is the sequel to the original [[Gradius]] and was succeeded by [i]Gradius III: From Legend to Myth[/i]. 

Ports of Gradius II were released for the [[Famicom]] (under the shortened title of Gradius II), [[PC Engine]] Super CD-ROM², and the Sharp [[X68000]] in Japan. 

The original arcade version is also included in the Gradius Deluxe Pack compilation for the [[PlayStation 1]] and [[Sega Saturn]] and in the Gradius Collection for the [[PlayStation Portable]].

title: macross_vf-x
body:
マクロス デジタルミッション VF-X ([b]Macross Digital Mission VF-X[/b]) is the first ever 3D graphics and polygonal videogame of the [[Macross]] franchise made by Bandai Visual for the [[Sony]] [[PlayStation 1]] in 1997. It was only released in Japan.

It is set in the year 2047 and the game focuses on a [[U.N. Spacy]] squadron assigned to rescue a girl band called the Milky Dolls. 

The game was re-released with a lower price as a PlayStation "The Best Collection Series" title in 1998.

A sequel called [[Macross VF-X2]] was released in 1999.

title: atou_(isekai_mokushiroku_mynoghra)
body:
One of Mynoghra's hero units and [[Ira Takuto]]'s favorite. In the new world she also counts as one of Idoragya's Seven Apocalypse-Bringing Evil Witches, being titled Sludge Witch Atou. She has a slender figure and pointy ears similar to an elf, but in reality she's a humanoid monster that can grow tentacles out of her back.

Her name is based on Ahtu, one of the avatars of Nyarlathotep in the expanded Cthulhu Mythos.

title: ira_takuto
body:
The protagonist of [[isekai mokushiroku mynoghra|Apocalypse Bringer Mynoghra]]. He reincarnated as the Nameless Evil God who commands the civilization Mynoghra from his favorite game. He's a teenager with short black hair, however he's seen by other characters as a misty black figure with bright eyes.

[spoiler]It's later revealed that he has an ability that allows him to perfectly imitate everything he defines himself to be, down to its last fiber and memory.[/spoiler]

title: antelise_antik
body: The mayor of the town of Dragontan in [[isekai mokushiroku mynoghra|Apocalypse Bringer Mynoghra]]. She's a voluptuous and alcoholic elf.

title: caria_elfuur
body:
One of the [[dark elf|dark elves]] from [[isekai mokushiroku mynoghra|Apocalypse Bringer Mynoghra]], she's [[Maria Elfuur]]'s [[twins|twin]] sister. Caria has [[burn scar]]s from head to toe in the right side of her body as a result of a plague.

[spoiler]The twins ate their own mother to survive a journey and they eventually start treating Isla as their second mother. When Isla is killed, they're requested to eat her heart to activate one of her skills, inheriting her hero unit status and the Hero's powers from another game, and together counting as one of Idoragya's Seven Apocalypse-Bringing Evil Witches, the Witches of Regret.[/spoiler]

title: maria_elfuur
body:

[spoiler]The twins ate their own mother to survive a journey and they eventually start treating Isla as their second mother. When Isla is killed, they're requested to eat her heart to activate one of her skills, inheriting her hero unit status and the Hero's powers from another game, and together counting as one of Idoragya's Seven Apocalypse-Bringing Evil Witches, the Witches of Regret.[/spoiler]

title: phantasy_star_universe
body:
A multiplayer online action role-playing game and successor to [i][[Phantasy Star Online]][/i] of the [i][[Phantasy Star]][/i] series by [[Sega]]. It was released in Japan on August 31, 2006 for the [[Playstation 2]] and PC, and on December 12, 2006 for the [[Xbox (original)|]]. It's North American release was on October 24, 2006, and in Europe on November 24th, 2006; both for all platforms.

The story and setting of [i]Phantasy Star Universe[/i], while similar, is not directly related to [i][[Phantasy Star Online]][/i]. It has, however, received an expansion, [i]Amibition of the Illuminus[/i], and series of sequels for the [[Playstation Portable]]:

* [[phantasy_star_portable]]
* [[phantasy_star_portable_2]]
* [[phantasy_star_portable_2_infinity]]

h4. Character Tags

Note: The traditional class names of the [i][[Phantasy Star Online]][/i] series do not to apply to [i]Phantasy Star Universe[/i]. It's no longer possible to identify classes by appearance alone since character outfits are available based on race, not class.

Instead of tagging classes, races can be tagged by their ears, using [[pointy_ears]], [[robot_ears]], and [[animal_ears]] for Newmans, CASTs, and Beasts, respectively.

title: metal_slug_3
body:
[b]Metal Slug 3[/b] is a run and gun [[video game]] developed by [[SNK]]. It was originally released in 2000 for the [[Neo Geo]] MVS [[arcade]] platform as the sequel to [[Metal Slug 2]]/[[Metal Slug X]]. The music of the game was developed by Noise Factory.

The game was ported to the [[PlayStation 2]], [[Xbox (original)|]], Microsoft Windows, iOS, Android, [[Wii]], [[PlayStation Portable]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[PlayStation Vita]], and [[Nintendo Switch]].

MS3 adds several features to the gameplay of the original [[Metal Slug]] and Metal Slug 2, such as weapons and vehicles, as well as introducing branching paths into the series which greatly increased its replayability. It received very positive reviews and is considered one of the best and most refined titles in the entire series (if not [b]the best Metal Slug[/b]).

title: need_for_speed:_most_wanted_(2005)
body:
Need for Speed: Most Wanted is a 2005 open-world racing video game, and the ninth installment in the [[Need for Speed]] series. Developed by EA Canada and EA Black Box and published by [[Electronic Arts]], it was released on November 11, 2005, for [[PlayStation 2]], [[Xbox (original)|]], [[GameCube]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Game Boy Advance]] and [[Xbox 360]]. An additional version, Need for Speed: Most Wanted 5-1-0, was released in the same year for [[PlayStation Portable]]. The game focuses on street racing-oriented gameplay involving a selection of events and racing circuits found within the fictional city of Rockport, with the game's main story involving players taking on the role of a street racer who must compete against 15 of the city's most elite street racers to become the most wanted racer of the group, in the process seeking revenge against one of the groups who took their car and developing a feud with the city's police department.

Most Wanted brought in many notable improvements and additions over other entries in the series, its major highlight being more in-depth [[police]] pursuits. Certain editions of the game were also packaged with the ability for online multiplayer gaming. Upon its release, the game received positive reviews from critics and became a commercial success, selling 16 million copies worldwide, becoming one of the best entries in the series as a result. Its success later led to a collector's edition, Black Edition, which provided additional content for the game.

The game was later succeeded by [[Need for Speed: Carbon]] in 2006, which provided a sequel to Most Wanted's story, with a virtual edition being made available for [[PlayStation 3]] via the PlayStation Store in May 2012, until it was discontinued the following year. A reboot of the game, developed by Criterion Games, was released in October 2012.

The cover car for the game is a customized version of the [[BMW M3]] GT-R racecar, which has since become one of the most iconic hero cars in the franchise and made return appearances in many succeeding titles.

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Need for Speed: Most Wanted (2005 video game)":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Need_for_Speed:_Most_Wanted_(2005_video_game)]

title: metal_wolf_chaos
body:
[b][i]METAL WOLF CHAOS[/i][/b] (メタルウルフカオス) is a 2004 video game developed by From Software for Microsoft's [[Xbox (original)|]]. It was never released outside of Japan, however, thanks to strong demand and interest generated by various Let's Plays on YouTube, indie game publishing label Devolver Digital along with partnership from General Arcade, they have released a remastered version, dubbed [i]METAL WOLF CHAOS XD[/i] in 2019 for PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and Windows PC.

title: phantasy_star_online
body:
[i]ファンタシースターオンライン[/i] (Phantasy Star Online) 

Science fantasy and magic action role-playing games and sub-series of [i][[Phantasy Star]][/i] made by [[Sega]]. It's well known as one of the first online multiplayer games for video game consoles. 

The series received several expansions after it's first release on the [[Sega Dreamcast]], starting with the updated edition Phantasy Star Online ver.2, followed by ports to both the [[Gamecube]] and [[Xbox (original)|]] as [i]Phantasy Star Online Episode I & II[/i]. The Gamecube also received a spin-off of the series, [i]Phantasy Star Online Episode III: C.A.R.D. Revolution[/i], with [[card]] based gameplay instead of the usual beat-em-up style. Finally, the series returned to form on the PC with release of [i]Phantasy Star Online: Blue Burst[/i], featuring Episode IV.

title: metal_slug_5
body:
[b]Metal Slug 5[/b] is a run and gun [[video game]] for the [[Neo Geo]] game system created by [[SNK]] Playmore. It was released in 2003 for the MVS [[arcade]] platform and is the fifth game in the [[Metal Slug]] series. 

The game was developed by Noise Factory/SNK Playmore, after Korean company Mega Enterprise had directed Metal Slug 4. [b]It was the last Metal Slug released on the Neo Geo home console.[/b]

It was later ported to Microsoft [[Xbox (original)|]] and [[PlayStation 2]] as a stand-alone game, and along with Metal Slug 4 as a compilation in North America and South Korea. It was ported to Microsoft Windows for a Korean release. A port was also released on the [[Nintendo Switch]] in 2018.

h4. See also

* [[Slug Gunner]]

title: section_z
body:
[b]Section Z[/b] (セクションZ, [i]Sekushon Z[/i]) is a side-scrolling shooter, [[science fiction]] [[video game]] by [[Capcom]], originally released as an [[arcade]] game in 1985. A home version was published for the [[famicom|Nintendo Entertainment System]] in 1987.

The arcade version was re-released as part of the [[Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 1]] game for the [[PlayStation 2]] and [[Xbox (original)|]], [[Capcom Classics Collection: Remixed]] for the [[PlayStation Portable]], and Capcom Arcade Cabinet for [[Xbox 360]] and [[PlayStation 3]].

h4.See also

* [[Side Arms Hyper Dyne]] - Spiritual sequel

title: metal_gear_solid_2:_sons_of_liberty
body:
[b]Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty[/b] is a 2001 stealth action [[video game]] developed by [[Konami]] Computer Entertainment Japan and published by Konami. Released on November 13, originally for the [[PlayStation 2]] it is the fourth [[metal_gear_(series)|Metal Gear game]] written and directed by [[Kojima Hideo]]. It is the seventh overall game in the series and is a direct sequel to the original [[Metal Gear Solid]], having [[Solid Snake]] as a protagonist. 

An expanded edition, titled [b]Metal Gear Solid 2: Substance[/b], was released the following year for [[Xbox (original)|]] and Microsoft Windows in addition to the PlayStation 2. A remastered version of the game was later included in the Metal Gear Solid HD Collection for the [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation Vita]], and [[Xbox 360]].

The story revolves around the Big Shell, a massive offshore clean-up facility seized by a group of terrorists who call themselves the titular "Sons of Liberty". They demand an enormous ransom in exchange for the life of the President of the United States and threaten to destroy the facility and create a cataclysmic environmental disaster if their demands are not met. The motives and identities of many of the antagonists and allies change throughout the course of the game, [spoilers]as the protagonists discover a world-shaking conspiracy constructed by a powerful organization known as the Patriots.[/spoilers]

Metal Gear Solid 2 received acclaim for its gameplay, graphics, and attention to detail. However, critics were initially divided on the protagonist and the philosophical nature and execution of the game's storyline, which explores themes such as the Information Age, [[meme]]tics, social engineering, political conspiracies, censorship, artificial intelligence, existentialism, postmodernism, virtual reality, and the internal struggle of political liberty and freedom of thought. 

The game was a commercial success, selling seven million copies by 2004. It has since been considered to be [b]one of the greatest video games of all time[/b], as well as a leading example of artistic expression in video games. The game is often considered ahead of its time for dealing with [[real life]] themes and concepts, such as post-truth politics, fake news, alternative facts, and echo chambers, that became culturally relevant in the 2010s.

A direct sequel called [[Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots]] was released in 2008.

h4.See also

* [[Raiden (Metal Gear)|]]
* [[Metal Gear Ray]]

title: magic_sword
body:
[b][i]Magic Sword[/i][/b] (マジックソード) fully titled as [b][i]Magic Sword: Heroic Fantasy[/i][/b], is a side-scrolling [[fantasy]] action [[arcade]] [[video game]] released by [[Capcom]] in 1990. 

The game casts the player as a hero who must fight his way through several levels of a mystical tower in order to save his world. 

The player can use a sword, axe, or magic, and can also rescue and recruit potential allies of various character classes, each of which has his or her own special abilities. 

The game was ported to the Super Famicon/[[Super Nintendo]] in 1992 and was compilated for the [[Xbox (original)|]], the [[Xbox 360]], the [[Playstation 2]] and [[Playstation 3]] several years later.

title: final_fight
body:
Groundbreaking arcade two player, cooperative, beat 'em-up [[video game]] released by [[Capcom]] in 1989.

It was ported to the Super Famicon and [[Super Nintendo]] home consoles and had two sequels exclusive for those two systems initially, as well as a Mega-CD/[[Sega]]-CD port and a [[Game Boy]] port (notable because it added character designs from the [[Street Fighter Zero (series)|]] series). There also have been several subsequent compilations of this video game for modern consoles in recent years.

[b][i]Final Fight[/i][/b] is included in the 2005 compilation [i]Capcom Classics Collection[/i] Volume 1 for the [[PlayStation 2]] and [[Xbox (original)|]], and in the 2006 portable version [i]Capcom Classics Collection Remixed[/i] for the [[PlayStation Portable]]. 

More recently, the arcade version of Final Fight was released in a two-in-one bundle titled [i]Final Fight: Double Impact[/i], alongside the arcade game [[Magic Sword]], for the [[Xbox 360]] Xbox Live Arcade and the [[Playstation 3]] PlayStation Network in 2010. 

Developers of the game have declared that it was partially inspired by the [[Double Dragon]] arcade hit Game from 1987 and also by an American 80s action/musical film called [i]"Streets of Fire":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streets_of_fire [/i] of which many of the production staff were fans.

The game is connected to the [[Street Fighter]] universe, with several characters from Final Fight have either made playable debut or featured as cameo.

title: xbox_360
body:
Is the second video [[game console]] produced by [[Microsoft]], and the successor to the [[Xbox (original)|]].

The [b]Xbox 360[/b] competes with [[Sony]]'s [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Nintendo]]'s [[Wii]] as part of the seventh generation of video game consoles. 

The [[Xbox logo]] is still the glowing green X, which - for the 360 - is embedded in a silver ball. The consoles main color is white, but it also comes in black with later productions in alternate colors.

Many accessories are available for the console, such as faceplates for customization.

title: raimais
body:
[b]Raimais[/b] (レイメイズ, [i]Reimeizu[/i]) is a maze chase [[science fiction]] [[cyberpunk]] [[arcade]] [[video game]] released in April 1988 in [[Japan]] by [[Taito]]. 

The object of the game is to drive your vehicle around a maze in order to clear the maze of dots while avoiding enemies (in a style similar to the old [[pac-man_(game)|Pac-Man]] game). The game consists of 32 mazes total plus boss fights (some optional, some not). 

Raimais was ported to the [[Famicom]] Disk System under the title [b]Youmais[/b] the same year. It was included as part of the compilation [[Taito Legends 2]] in 2006 for the [[Xbox (original)|]] and [[PlayStation 2]] consoles as well as Microsoft [[Windows]] [[computer]]s, marking its first official release in the west. 

It was also re-released as part of the [i]Arcade Archives[/i] lineup on the [[PlayStation 4]] and [[Nintendo Switch]] on November 18, 2021, worldwide.

title: metal_slug_4
body:
[b]Metal Slug 4[/b] is a run and gun [[video game]] for the [[Neo Geo]] console/[[arcade]] platform created by Mega Enterprise along with Noise Factory. It was released in 2002 for the Neo Geo MVS arcade platform, and is the fourth game in the [[Metal Slug]] series. 

Two years later, Playmore published Metal Slug 4 for consoles.

Metal Slug 4 retains the same gameplay as previous titles, with the addition of some enemies, bosses, weapons, several vehicles and a bonus combo system. It was ported to [[Xbox (original)|]] and [[PlayStation 2]] as a stand-alone game in Japan and Europe, and along with [[Metal Slug 5]] as a compilation in North America and South Korea. The [[Nintendo Switch]] version was released in 2018.

title: gamecube
body:
The [b]Nintendo GameCube[/b] is [[Nintendo]]'s fourth home video [[game console]] released in 2001.

The successor to the [[Nintendo 64]]. As part of the sixth generation of gaming, the GameCube competed with the [[Sega Dreamcast]] (which ceased production before the GameCube launched), [[Sony]]'s [[PlayStation 2]], and [[Microsoft]]'s [[Xbox (original)|]].

It was succeeded by the Nintendo [[Wii]].
h4. See also
* [[List of game consoles]]

title: xbox_(original)
body:
A video game console produced by [[Microsoft]], and their very first console produced by the company.

The Xbox logo is a glowing green X, surrounded by black space. On the console, the name "XBOX" is placed in a large green circle.
The main color of Xbox is black, with later productions in alternate colors. It was later succeeded by the [[Xbox 360]].

Note that this tag is for the original Xbox console, [b]NOT[/b] the Xbox brand as a whole. Not to be confused with [[Xbox One]], the successor of Xbox 360. If the post only features the logo of the Xbox brand and haven't made any reference to the console, tag [[Xbox logo]] instead.

title: soviet_border_troops
body:
[[Russian text|Russian]]: [b]Пограничные войска СССР[/b], [[romaji text|romanized]]: [i]Pogranichnyye voyska SSSR[/i]

THe border guard of the [[soviet|USSR]] subordinated to the Soviet state security agency: first to the Cheka/OGPU, then to [[NKVD]]/MGB and, finally, to the [[KGB]]. Accordingly, they were known as NKVD Border Security and KGB Border Troops. Unlike the border guards of many other countries, Soviet Border Troops also included the maritime border guarding units, and aviation units (i.e., a coast guard).

The mission of Border Troops included repulsing armed incursions into Soviet territory; preventing illegal crossings of the border or the transport of [[weapon]]s, [[explosive]]s, or contraband or across the border; monitoring the observance of established procedures at border crossing points; monitoring the observance by Soviet and foreign [[ship]]s of navigation procedures in Soviet territorial [[water]]s; and assisting state agencies in the preservation of natural resources and the protection of the environment from pollution. Border guards were authorized to examine documents and possessions of persons crossing the borders and to confiscate articles; to conduct inquiries in cases of violations of the state border; and to take such actions as arrest, search and interrogation of individuals suspected of border violations. 

They are easily distinguished with [b]green colouring[/b] on their [[uniform]]s. This includes [[beret]]s, [[collar tabs]], [[patch]]es, [[peaked cap]]s as well as shoulder [[epaulettes]] that usually has Cyrillic acronym "ПВ" on them. See post #3743293 and post #5953554 for examples.

h4. See also
* [[Grenztruppen]] - [[East Germany|East German]] counterpart
* [[Spetsnaz]]
* [[Soviet Army]]
* [[Soviet Air Force]]
* [[Soviet Militsiya]]
* [[Soviet Navy]]
* [[Pioneer Movement|Soviet Pioneer]]
* Wikipedia article: "Soviet Border Troops":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Border_Troops]

title: berlin
body:
[b]Berlin[/b] (/bɜːrˈlɪn/ bur-LIN, German: [bɛʁˈliːn] i) is the capital and largest city of [[Germany]] by both area and population.  

Its more than 3.85 million inhabitants make it the European Union's most populous city, according to population within city limits. 

Berlin straddles the banks of the Spree, which flows into the Havel (a tributary of the Elbe) in the western borough of Spandau. Among the city's main topographical features are the many lakes in the western and southeastern boroughs formed by the Spree, Havel and Dahme, the largest of which is Lake Müggelsee. Due to its location in the European Plain, Berlin is influenced by a temperate seasonal climate. About one-third of the city's area is composed of forests, parks, gardens, rivers, canals, and lakes. The city lies in the Central German dialect area, the Berlin dialect being spoken.

First documented in the 13th century and at the crossing of two important historic trade routes, Berlin became the capital of the Margraviate of Brandenburg (1417–1701), Kingdom of Prussia (1701–1918), German Empire (1871–1918), Weimar Republic (1919–1933), and [[Nazi]] Germany (1933–1945). Berlin has served as a scientific, artistic and philosophical hub of the Enlightenment, Neoclassicism, and liberal revolution. The Gründerzeit era's industrialization-induced economic boom multiplied Berlin's population rapidly. Berlin in the roaring 1920s was the third-largest city in the world by population.

After [[World War II]] and its [[battle of berlin|subsequent occupation]] by the victorious countries, the devastated city was divided during the [[Cold War]]; West Berlin became a de facto exclave of [[West Germany]], surrounded by the [[Berlin Wall]] (from August 1961 to November 1989) and East German territory. East Berlin was declared capital of [[East Germany]], while [[Bonn]] became the West German capital. Following German reunification in 1990, Berlin once again became the capital of all of Germany.

Berlin is a world city of culture, politics, media and science. Its economy is based on high-tech firms and the service sector, encompassing a diverse range of creative industries, startup companies, research facilities, media corporations, and convention venues. Berlin serves as a continental hub for air and rail traffic and has a highly complex public transportation network. The metropolis is a popular tourist destination. Significant industries also include information technology, healthcare, biomedical engineering, biotechnology, automotive, construction, electronics, social economy and clean tech.

Berlin is home to world-renowned universities such as the Humboldt University, Technical University, Free University, University of the Arts, ESMT Berlin, Hertie School, and Bard College Berlin. Its Zoological Garden is the most visited zoo in Europe and one of the most popular worldwide. With Babelsberg being the world's first large-scale movie studio complex, Berlin is an increasingly popular location for international film productions. The city is well known for its festivals, diverse architecture, nightlife, contemporary arts, and high quality of life.

Berlin is also home to three World Heritage Sites: Museum Island; the Palaces and Parks of Potsdam and Berlin; and the Modernism Housing Estates. Other landmarks include the [[Brandenburg Gate]], [[Reichstag]] building, Potsdamer Platz, Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe, Berlin Wall Memorial, East Side Gallery, Berlin Victory Column, Berlin Cathedral, and [[Berlin Television Tower]], the tallest structure in Germany. Berlin has numerous museums, galleries, libraries, orchestras, and sporting events including Museum Island, the German Historical Museum, Jewish Museum, Natural History Museum, State Library, State Opera, Philharmonic, and the Berlin Marathon.

title: soviet
body:
Anything related to the former Soviet Union, and, to a wider extent, the Warsaw Pact.

The [b]Soviet Union[/b] (1917-1991), officially the [b]Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR)[/b], was a vast [[communism|communist]] federated state in what is today [[Russia]] and other adjacent nations with a state ideology of [[Karl Marx|Marxism]]-[[Vladimir Lenin|Leninism]]. The Warsaw Pact was a collective defense treaty created in response to the expansion NATO, led largely in the foreign policy interests of the Soviet Union, including the remaining communist states in Europe of the era, sans [[Yugoslavia]] and, later, Albania, with key world allies such as Marxist-Leninist [[Cuba]], although the tag should not apply to states that did not constitute the Soviet Union.

This tag can refer to a) Soviet-related iconography, such as the [[Hammer and Sickle]], [[Red Star]], Soviet-stylized [[Cyrillic]], [[russian_text|Russian]], or other text; or b) posts that either show a location within the Soviet Union during the period of its existence, or are indicated as being of the general era when the Soviet Union or Warsaw Pact existed (based on architecture, attire, technology, etc.), in which case the post would be tagged with this tag and the respective country tag (if one applies), e.g., like [i]{{soviet russia}}[/i] or [i]{{soviet ukraine}}[/i].

h4. Related tags

title: ak-74
body:
The [B]AK-74[/B] ([b]А[/b]втомат [b]К[/b]алашникова образца 19[b]74[/b] года 'Kalashnikov assault rifle model 1974') is a 5.45×39mm [b][[assault rifle]][/b], developed in Izhevsk Mechanical Plant, 1974. It largely replaced the larger-caliber [[AKM]] in [[Soviet]] service, and many of its parts are interchangeable with the earlier [[kalashnikov rifle|AKs]]. First used by Soviet [[military|forces]] during the [[war in afghanistan|Afghanistan conflict]] from 1979.

Use this tag solely if the [[weapon]] is depicted with full-bodied, fixed stock, and these characteristics: [tn](post #5952944 as an example)[/tn]
* Common presence of synthetic brown/orange furniture (pistol grip and handguard), as well as the magazines.
* Distinctive, longer, non-canted [[muzzle device]]/[[muzzle device]].
* Fixed stock has elongated indentations on both sides.
* Less-curved [[magazine (weapon)|magazine]] profile due to smaller [[rifle cartridge|cartridges]].
* Stamped receiver with visible rivets and smaller rectangular indentation on it.

h4. See also
* [[AK-74M]]
* [[AKS-74]]
** [[MPi-AKS-74]] [tn][[East Germany|East German]] variant[/tn]
* [[AKS-74U]]
* [[List of weapons]]
* [[RPK-74]]

h4. External links

title: strichtarn
body:
A [[military]] [[camouflage]] pattern developed in [[East Germany]]. It was adopted by the [[Nationale Volksarmee]] in 1965, used until 1990. The name is a [[German text|German]] word for "line camouflage". The pattern consists of broken vertical red-brown [[dotted line|lines]] on a grey-green field, which was also known as the raindrop pattern.

h4. External links 
* Wikipedia article: "Strichtarn":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strichtarn]

title: trabant
body:
Series of [[East Germany|East German]] small [[car]]s manufactured by VEB Sachsenring from 1957 to 1990. The body is unusually made out of duroplast, has a low power engine, and known for poor reliability issues.

This tag applies to all [[motor vehicle|the models]], such as the Trabant 500, Trabant 600, Trabant 601, and the Trabant 1.1.

h4. See also
* [[List of Ground Vehicles]]

title: nationale_volksarmee
body:
[b]The National People's Army[/b] (German: [i]Nationale Volksarmee[/i], pronounced [natsi̯oˈnaːlə ˈfɔlksʔaʁˌmeː]; NVA [ɛn faʊ ˈʔaː]) were the armed forces of the German Democratic Republic (GDR) from 1956 to 1990.

Also known as the [b]Army of [[East Germany]][/b], it was one of the few Warsaw Pact forces that received [[Soviet Army]] top of the line [[military]] equipment during the [[Cold War]] as East Germany was one of the few communist countries that was closer to the enemy nations members of the NATO.

In a state of constant readiness and due to frequent battle drills, it was considered one of the best trained and best prepared and equipped armed forces of the Warsaw Pact, probably even more so than the [[Soviet Army]] itself according to some experts.

h4. See also

* [[NVA uniform]]
* [[Stahlhelm M1956]]

title: mpi-km
body:
[[East Germany|East German]] variant of the [[AKM]] [B][[assault rifle]][/b]. It's distinct feature is the pebble-grain pattern on the fixed buttstock (see post #3980993) and early models do not have slanted muzzle brake. 

h4. See also
* [[Kalashnikov rifle]]
* [[List of weapons]]
* [[MPi-KMS-72]] [tn]([[folding stock]] variant)[/tn]

h4. External links
* "Wikipedia":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AKM#East_Germany

title: wieger_stg-940
body:
The [b]Wieger StG-940[/b] was an [[East Germany|East German]] series of 5.56×45mm NATO [[assault rifle]]s loosely based upon the [[kalashnikov rifle|AK-74]], intended for export. Visually recognizable by its clubfoot-shaped buttstock or clothes hanger-shaped [[folding stock|folding one]], slimline two-piece polymer handguard without ventilations, threaded muzzle and all-black finish. 

h4. See also
* [[List of Weapons]]
* [[StG-940 (Girls' Frontline)]]

h4. External links
* "Wikipedia: Wieger StG-940":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wieger_StG-940

title: stahlhelm_m1956
body:
The [b]Stahlhelm M1956[/b] or [b]M56[/B] was the official [[combat helmet]] of the [[East Germany|East German]] [[military]] ([[Nationale Volksarmee]]) during the [[Cold War]], introduced in 1956. It is a native German experimental design from 1942 originally intended as an evolution and successor to the iconic Stahlhelm from the two World Wars but never adopted since [[Adolf Hitler]] considered it too similar to Allied helmets of the time. 

The new sloped angular shape supposedly gave the new [[helmet]] more resistance to bullet hits.  
For the earlier World War I and II predecessor, use only [b][[Stahlhelm]][/b].

h4. See also
* [[Strichtarn]]
* [[Tag Group:Headwear]]

title: east_german_flag
body: The flag of [[East Germany]] features the same black/red/gold tricolor of the [[German flag]], with the addition of the national emblem of East Germany in the centre. The emblem consists of a [[hammer]] (representing workers) and [[compass_(instrument)|compass]] (representing intelligentsia) surrounded by a [[wreath]] of [[wheat|wheat ears]] (representing farmers).

title: toyota_hilux
body:
A line of small [[pickup truck]]s produced by [[Toyota]] since 1988. An even more barebones variant called the [[Toyota Hilux Champ]] has been sold in Southeast Asian countries since 2023.

Notorious for their use as [[technical]]s in various conflicts around the world.

title: despicable_me
body:
Despicable Me is a 2010 American computer-animated 3D comedy film from Universal Pictures and Illumination Entertainment that was released on July 9, 2010 in the [[United States]]. It is Illumination Entertainment's first film. It was directed by Pierre Coffin and Chris Renaud, based on an original story by Sergio Pablos. Famous for the yellow [[minion (despicable me)|]]s.

h4. See also
* [Wikipedia article](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Despicable_Me)
* [TV Tropes page](http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/WesternAnimation/DespicableMe)

title: minamoto_kou
body:
A character from [[Jibaku Shounen Hanako-kun]].

[[Minamoto Teru|Teru]] is his older brother, and [[minamoto tiara|Tiara]] is his younger sister. 

He is part of the Minamoto Clan, a family of renowned exorcists. Like his older brother, he's sometimes depicted holding a [[shakujou]] (pewter staff).

* !post #5988367: Official anime art

title: minamoto_teru
body:
A character from [[Jibaku Shounen Hanako-kun]].

[[Minamoto Kou|Kou]] is his younger brother, and [[minamoto tiara|Tiara]] is his younger sister. 

He is part of the Minamoto Clan, a family of renowned exorcists. As such, he's sometimes depicted holding a [[shakujou]] (pewter staff).

title: minamoto_tiara
body:
A character from [[Jibaku Shounen Hanako-kun]].

[[Minamoto Kou|Kou]] is her older brother, and [[Minamoto Teru|Teru]] is her eldest brother.

title: aventail
body: A curtain of [[chainmail]] attached to the skull of a [[helmet]] such as a [[bascinet]] that extends to cover at least the neck, but often also the throat and shoulders.

title: cervelliere
body: A a hemispherical, close-fitting metal [[skullcap]] first worn in the 12th Century. It was worn either alone or more often over or under a [[chainmail]] [[coif]]. It was sometimes worn underneath a larger [[great helm]].

title: bascinet
body: A type of [[helmet]] worn during the 14th and early 15th Centuries, characterized by a relatively high, pointed skull and extending downwards at the rear and sides to afford protection for the neck. Often worn with an [[aventail]] and detachable visors like the [[hounskull]]. Not to be confused with a [[bassinet]].

title: bassinet
body:
A basket, usually hooded, that serves as a baby's bed.

Not to be confused with a [[bascinet]], which is a type of medieval helmet.

title: bevor
body: A piece of [[plate armor]] designed to protect the neck and mouth, often worn in conjunction with a [[sallet]].

title: estelle_bright
body: The main heroine of the [[Sora no Kiseki]] trilogy, she is a naive and straightforward girl who is always energetic and positive. She is very boyish in appearance and attitude, and has a "hit first and ask later" attitude. Daugher of [[Cassius Bright]] and foster sister of [[Joshua Bright]] (do not use [[brother and sister]] for Joshua and her).

title: yamato_(one_piece)
body:
[[One Piece]] character. Daughter of [[Kaidou (one piece)|]], albeit she proclaims herself to be a "man" and initially dressed as such [spoiler]due to her encounter with [[Kouzuki Oden]] leaving such a strong impression on her that she wanted to become a "man" to leave Wano and undertake an adventure like him[/spoiler].

Like her father, Yamato has inherited the dragon blood and as such she is [[tall female|significantly taller than an average woman]], standing at 263 cm.

Having consumed the Inu Inu no Mi, Model: Okuchi no Makami [[Devil Fruit]], she can transform into a divine [[wolf]] and is capable of freezing things around her.

title: ruri_dragon
body:
Manga series written and illustrated by Shindou Masaoki (眞藤雅興). The first chapter was published on June 13th, 2022 in issue 28 of [[shounen jump|Weekly Shōnen Jump]].

It's a story of a young [[dragon girl]] [[Aoki Ruri]] being lazy, doing her best... and being lazy again.

h4. Characters

* [[Aoki Ruri]] - Main Character
* [[Aoki Umi]] - Ruri's Mom
* [[Kashiro (ruri_dragon)|]]  - Ruri's classmate who sits next to her.  She has [[multicolored hair]] with dyed [[twintails]] extending just past the shoulders. Full name unavailable thus far. 
* [[Maeda Akari (ruri_dragon)|]]
* [[Yuka (ruri_dragon)|]] - Ruri's old Friend who she often heads to school with.  Full name unavailable thus far. 

h4. External links
* WSJ Page: "『ルリドラゴン』｜集英社『週刊少年ジャンプ』公式サイト":[https://www.shonenjump.com/j/rensai/ruri.html]
